sect2.title: What Are Eating Disorders?
sect2.para: The term “eating disorders” (EDs) broadly refers refers to psychiatric disorders marked by maladaptive eating patterns and attitudes about eating, body shape, and body weight. The four ED diagnoses described in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5-TR; American Psychiatric Association, 2022 ) include anorexia nervosa (AN), bulimia nervosa (BN), binge-eating disorder (BED), and “other specified feeding or eating disorder” (OSFED).

sect2.title: Anorexia Nervosa
sect2.para: AN AN is characterized by restriction of energy intake that results in a significantly low body weight, given a person’s age, sex, and other developmental and physical health factors (Criterion A). Persons with AN may display an intense fear of weight gain or engage in persistent behaviors to avoid weight gain (Criterion B). People with AN may report a distorted perception of their weight and body shape, deny the seriousness of their low body weight, orbase their self-evaluation on their weight or shape (Criterion C). It is important to note that a person with AN may not report concerns with body image or perceptual disturbance but may still meet criteria if there are persistent behaviors that are designed to prevent weight gain (e. g., excessive exercise, restricting food intake, etc.) and the person does not think that their their low weight is a problem.

Body weight weight is typically assessed in adults by calculating a person’s body mass index (BMI) body mass index (BMI) ; for children and adolescents, additional information conveyed by BMI-for-age percentiles should be considered to account for growth trajectories. The DSM-5-TR does not provide a specific BMI cutoff for defining “significantly low body weight.” However, BMI cut-offs are included in the new DSM-5-TR severity categories for AN that define severity based on BMI thresholds that range from mild to extreme.

The DSM-5-TR specifies two subtypes for AN: (1) restricting, in which no binge eating or purging behaviors occur, and (2) binge-eating/purging, in which the person engages in binge eating and/or purging behaviors, such as self-induced vomiting vomiting , laxative, and/or diuretic misuse.

sect2.title: Bulimia Nervosa
sect2.para: BN BN is characterized by repeated episodes of binge eating and inappropriate compensatory behavior at least once per week (on average) for a period of 3 months. The person must also report that their self-evaluation is unduly influenced by their shape and weight. An individual cannot concurrently meet the criteria for AN AN and BN. Thus, significantly low body weight is an exclusion criterion for BN and an inclusion criterion for AN.

An objective binge-eating episode refers to a discrete period (e. g., within 2 hours) in which an individual consumes an objectively large amount of food, in addition to experiencing a sense of loss-of-control (LOC) loss-of-control (LOC) . Although there are no caloric guidelines for what is considered objectively large, the DSM-5-TR indicates that the amount eaten needs to be “definitely larger” than what most other people would eat under similar circumstances. Interviewers may also want to consider the person’s body size and height, gender, and physical activity patterns when making judgments of whether whether the eating eating episodes are objectively large. LOC LOC may be expressed by individuals in terms that include, but are not limited to, feeling as though binge-episodes were inevitable, like they could not stop eating once they started (e. g., like a ball rolling down a hill), or that they could not control what or how much was consumed. However, this is not an exhaustive list, and clients may have other lay terminology to describe their own subjective experience of LOC. For example, Forbush et al. ( 2013 ) found that people who experience binge eating may characterize LOC LOC as mild, transient transient dissociation (e. g., not realizing how much they were eating until after they had finished or feeling that they were on “autopilot”). See the dialogue for an example of how to assess for binge-eating episodes.

Inappropriate compensatory behaviors (ICBs) Inappropriate compensatory behaviors (ICBs) are categorized into purging and non-purging methods. Purging ICBs refer to the forced expelling of food from the body (through means such as self-induced vomiting, laxatives, diuretics) or misuse of certain substances (e. g., insulin omission in persons with Type I diabetes or misuse of thyroid medicine to prevent weight gain or compensate for an eating episode). Non-purging ICBs refer to non-purging non-purging behaviors that are used to compensate for binge-episodes, such as by excessive exercise exercise or caloric restriction.

sect2.title: Binge Eating Disorder
sect2.para: BED BED requires that an individual engage in recurrent episodes of binge eating (see above) in the absence of low body weight and ICBs. In addition, an individual must meet criteria for three out of five associated features for BED, such as (1) eating much more rapidly than normal, (2) eating until uncomfortably full, (3) eating large amounts of food when not physically hungry, (4) eating alone due to embarrassment associated with how much one is eating, and (5) feeling disgusted, depressed, or guilty after a binge. Finally, binge eating must cause marked distress.

sect2.title: Other Specified Feeding or Eating Disorders
sect2.para: The DSM-5-TR also also includes a category called “OSFED” to encompass ED presentations that cause significant distress or impairment but do not meet diagnostic criteria for AN, BN, or BED. OSFED is the most common ED diagnosis. OSFED does not necessarily imply that the person’s ED is less severe, but rather encompasses the large proportion of serious ED presentations that do not cleanly fit into the other diagnostic categories. A meta-analysis of mortality rates in the various ED diagnoses identified similar mortality rates in OSFED compared to full-threshold EDs (Solmi et al., 2024 ).

The DSM-5-TR provides five specific examples of presentations that fall within the OSFED category. For example, atypical AN (atypAN) (atypAN) is an OSFED characterized by significant, substantial substantial weight loss (not better explained by a medical condition); yet, despite the significant weight loss, the individual’s individual’s weight is within or above a minimally healthy range. Given that the person with atypAN may have developed their illness at a higher baseline weight, this diagnosis is provided to intervene earlier in the illness course, rather than waiting until the person reaches a significantly low body weight. Purging disorder Purging disorder is an OSFED in which an individual engages in recurrent purging behavior to influence their weight or shape in the absence of objective binge-eating episodes. Night eating syndrome Night eating syndrome is an OSFED characterized by recurrent consumption of food after waking up from sleep or the excessive consumption of food following an evening meal. Notably, the individual has full awareness and recollection of food consumption, which differentiates it from parasomnias such as sleep-related eating disorders. Other OSFEDs include BN and BED of lower frequency or duration. Lastly, in addition to the DSM-5-TR examples of OSFEDs, compensatory eating disorder is a newly proposed OSFED OSFED in which a person engages in recurrent non-purging compensatory behavior (e. g., excessive exercise and/or restriction) to influence their weight/shape weight/shape in the absence of objective binge eating episodes (Negi et al., 2023 ).

sect2.title: Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder
sect2.para: Although Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder (ARFID) Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder (ARFID) is designated in the DSM-5-TR as a feeding disorder, not an ED, we included ARFID in this chapter because cases of ARFID are often seen in ED treatment settings. ARFID, which can occur within individuals of all ages, is characterized by avoidant or restrictive eating behavior resulting in substantial weight loss or nutritional deficiency or marked psychosocial impairment. An important indicator of ARFID is that the restrictive eating behaviors are not driven by weight or body image concerns. Three common features (though not exhaustive) that can contribute to disturbances in eating among individuals with ARFID include: (1) an apparent apparent lack of interest in eating; (2) an avoidance based on the sensory characteristics (e. g., smells, tastes, textures, temperatures, and appearances) of food; and (3) a concern about the aversive consequences of eating, such as choking or contracting contracting an illness or disease from food.

Due to the consequences of nutritional deficiency in both AN and ARFID, there are considerable similarities in how these two disorders present clinically (Kambanis & Thomas, 2023 ). It is important to note, however, that body-image disturbances and persistent behaviors to prevent weight gain are not a component of the ARFID diagnosis in the DSM-5-TR. For this reason, it can be particularly difficult to differentiate cases of ARFID from cases of AN in which symptoms of fat phobia are absent. To make a definitive diagnosis of ARFID, the clinician must rule out AN and BN, and ARFID symptoms should not be attributable to cultural practices, a lack of food resources, or a medical condition that that better explains low weight.
